lines.text: I suppose none of this could ever really have worked. I do love you Jimmy, I shall never love anyone as I love you, but I can't go on, I can't take part in all this suffering, I can't.

It's no good fooling about with love you know. You can't fall into it like a soft job without dirtying up your hands. It takes muscle and guts. If you can't bear the thought of messing up your nice, tidy soul, you better give up the whole idea of life and become a saint, because you'll never make it as a human being. It's either this world... or the next.

Hardly a moment when I'm not watching, wanting you. Nearly 2 years in the same room as you and I still can't stop my sweat breaking out when I see you do something as ordinary as cooking or leaning over the ironing board. Trouble is... you get used to people, even their trivialities become indispensable to you.

[on bears and squirrels]
Its sort of a silly symphony for people who can't bear the pain of being human any longer.
Nigel and Alison, they're what they sound like, sycophantic, phlegmatic and pusillanimous.
Big words.
Shall I tell you what they mean?
No not interested, don't want to know.
Soapy, stodgy and dim.
Do you know brother Nigel?
No I don't.
You never heard so many well-bred commonplaces come from beneath the same bowler hat, the platitude from outer space, that's brother Nigel.
I don't think I want anything more to do with love. Not any more, I can't take it on.
Ladies and gentlemen, a little recitation entitled 'she was only a gravediggers daughter but she loved lying under the sod'.
I'm sorry.
Get out.
You think I did it on purpose?
Clear out of my sight!
You're a brave girl.
I don't feel very brave Cliff, I really don't. I don't think I can take much more, I feel rather sick.

I keep looking back as far as I remember. I can't think what it was like to feel young, really young. Jimmy said the same thing to me the other day and I pretended not to be listening because I thought it would hurt him I suppose. But I knew just what he meant. Oh I suppose it would've been so easy to say 'oh yes darling, I know what you mean, I know how you're feeling'. Its these easy things that seem to be so impossible with us.
14lbs of jelly babies, what do you want to get all them for?
Kids have got a craze on.
They better have.
What does your husband do, what's his profession?
He runs a sweet stall at the market.
I thought you said he's been to university.
I'm getting hungry.
You're a bloody pig.

You're like a sex maniac only with you it's food - you'll end up in the News of the World, you wait - James Porter, 25, was bound over last night after pleading guilty to interfering with a small cabbage and a tin of beans. The accused said he hadn't been feeling well for some time and had been having blackouts.
Look down your nose at her once more...
I just couldn't bear to be touched.
You made that perfectly plain.

I'm just going to have a look at me husband's grave, make sure it's kept nice. You know, if you don't keep an eye on things people steal the flower boxes and grass grows all over the place. I wouldn't want him to think I was neglecting him.
We had lots of fun, him and me. Being alive, just being alive. That's enough for an old girl like me. Chewing the cud and having a little of what you fancy.
What do you *really* want, Jimmy?
Everything... nothing.
What friend?
Helena Charles, I meant to say, she telephoned, she's playing at the theatre next week.
I see, she said 'can I come over' and you said 'My husband Jimmy, if you'll pardon my using such a dirty word, will be delighted to see you, he'll kick your teeth in'.
Does he drink?
He's not an alcoholic if that's what you mean.
Oh, that trumpet! It's almost as if he wanted to kill someone and me in particular. I've never seen such hatred in someone's eyes before, it's horrifying... and slightly exciting.
Tell me, why did you?

Marry him? Oh there must be about six different answers. I met him at a party, he'd come there on his bicycle and there was oil on his jacket, it had been such a lovely day, everything about him seemed to burn - his face, the edges of his hair glistened. His eyes were so blue and full of sun.
So you took him on.
There never seemed to be any choice.
Did he love you?
A howl of outrage went up from my family.
Well, you can see their point.
And that made up his mind, he had to marry me.
Anyone who doesn't like jazz has no real feeling for music, or people.
Rubbish.
I think you're a very tiresome young man.
Oh dear, oh dear, my wife's friends. Pass Lady Bracknell the cucumber sandwiches.
What about you, do you want to come?
I'm going out with Helena.
That's not a direction, its an affliction.
He doesn't know what love or anything else means.
I must say it's pretty dreary living in the American age, apart from if you're an American of course.
Are you a good actress?
Oh really!
Since we're going to have you for 2 solid weeks I only hope its going to be worthwhile, that it adds to the sum of human happiness.
Shall I tell you the truth about her? She is a cow. I wouldn't mind that so much only she's in great danger of becoming a sacred cow as well.
You know mummy and I took a quick look at each other and from then on the age of chivalry was dead.
Don't brawl boyo, it won't do any good.
Why not, it's the only thing I'm good at.
If you slap me, by God I'll lay you out.
You would, you're the type.
You bet I'm the type, the type that hates physical violence.
Going out, on a Sunday evening this time, where have you got to be?
She's coming with me to church.
You're doing what? When I think of what I did, what I had to endure!
Shut up - you've no right to talk about her mother like that.

I've every right haven't I. She's an old cow and she should be dead. Well, what's the matter, why don't you spring to her defense? If someone said that about me she'd react soon enough - she'd spring into a well-known lethargy and say nothing.
Well, what's the matter with you?
I just feel quite sick, that's all. Sick with contempt and loathing.
She's taken you with her and you're so bloody wet you've let her do it.
All I want is a little peace.
I want to be there when your face is rubbed in the mud. There's nothing else I can hope for any more, there's nothing else I want anymore.
There's a call for you downstairs.
Can't be anything good.
You just sit there and do nothing.
That's right, I just sit here.
What sort of a man are you.
I'm not the district commissioner you know.
I love those two people very much and I pity all of us.
I don't understand you or him or any of it.
Have you ever seen anybody die?
No I haven't.

For 12 months I watched my father die, I was 10. He'd come back from the war in Spain. All my mother could think was that she'd married someone who was always on the wrong side. Perhaps she pitied him but I was the only one who cared.
I learned at an early age what it is to be angry. Angry. Helpless.

[Last words]
Don't let yourself down.
You know what he said about mummy, he said she was an overfed, overprivileged old cow.
I see, and what did he say about me?
He doesn't seem to mind you, in fact I think he rather likes you. Poor old daddy, just one of those sturdy plants left over from the Edwardian era wondering why the sun doesn't shine any more.
Why did you have to meet this young man?
Oh daddy, please don't put me on trial now. I've been on trial every day and night for the past two years.
But why you, my daughter?
You're hurt because everything's changed and Jimmy's hurt because everything's stayed the same. Something's gone wrong somewhere hasn't it.
If you'd stop thinking about yourself for just one moment, I'll tell you something I think you ought to know. You wife is going to have a baby!
[pause]
Well? Doesn't that mean anything? Even to you?

[pause]
If you'd permit me to interrupt your... female wisdom, there's something perhaps you ought to know. I don't care! I don't care if she's going to have a baby. I don't care if it has 2 heads!
[pause]

Well, do I disgust you? Go on, slap my face! I just came back from seeing somebody I love very much go through the sordid process of dying. And you expect me to be overcome with awe because some stupid, cruel girl is going to have a BABY?
[pause]
Now the performance is over. Now leave me alone - and get out, you evil-minded little virgin!
How was it?
It was a funeral... no flowers, no word, no sign...
What do you mean?
I mean Alison... the injustice of it is about perfect - the wrong people going hungry, the wrong people being loved, the wrong people dying.
Why do we spend half Sunday reading the newspapers?
Never used to know whether he was joking or being serious.
He doesn't know himself half the time - if in doubt mark it down as an insult.

[singing]
Don't be afraid to sleep with your sweetheart, just because she's better than you.
I think you take after me my dear, you like to sit on the fence. Its comfortable and more peaceful.
Sitting on the fence - I married him didn't I?
It's not the same, is it?
Of course not, it's never the same you idiot. Today's meal is always different from yesterday's, the last woman is always different from the one before.
Don't think I'll stay much longer.
Why not?
I don't know, sweet store's alright but I'd like to try something else. You're highly educated, it suits you, but I need something a bit better.
Sorry he's gone.
So am I. He's sloppy and irritating but he's got a good heart, you can forgive someone almost anything for that.
I love you.
Perhaps you do, perhaps it means something to have your General lie back in your arms though he's heartily sick of the whole campaign. Tired, hungry and dry.
Look if you don't want to watch the film, don't spoil it for those that do. If they don't like this country why the hell don't they get out.
God Jimmy, what's going to become of us?
I don't know.

You know what Alison once said, you were born out of your time. I think I know what she means - sometimes I think you feel you're still in the middle of the French Revolution. Oh Jimmy, can't you give up that sweet shop and do something else?
Such as?
I don't know, there are so many things that you could do.

Such as being a literary gent - Porter the lion of the pen club, laughing Porter the tv panelist, Lord Porter leaving no.10. The personality of Porter - lets examine it, that glittering meteoric cause. While the rest of the world is being blown to bits around us what matters - me, me me.
What made you come to this bloody country anyway?
I came because in India I was an outcast, an untouchable.
I am most interested in justice but I am not in the habit of expecting it to be applied to me.
My feet hurt.
Try washing your socks.
All because I want something from that girl I know in my heart she's incapable of giving.
What do you say we get out of this place and start from scratch, what do you say?
I'd say that's wonderful.
Come on, we'll do that. We'll get pleasantly tiddly, then I'll take you home and make such love to you as you'll forget about anything at all.
Let's go and have a drink.
Alison, it's all over.
I didn't know about the baby. I don't exactly relish the idea of pain and suffering but it wasn't my first loss you know.
It was mine.

Remember that time we first met, grisly party. Didn't really notice me at all. I couldn't take my eyes off you all evening. You seemed to have such a wonderful relaxation of spirit. I knew that was what I wanted. Then after we were married I realised it wasn't relaxation after all. To relax you've got to sweat your guts out. You, you never had a hair out of place or a bead of sweat anywhere. I know I'm a lost caues but I thought if you loved me it didn't really matter.

It does matter, I was wrong. I don't want to be neutral, I want to be a lost cause. Don't you understand - it's gone, that helpless human being inside my body. I thought it was so safe and secure in there but its gone. All I wanted was to die. I was in pain and all I could think about was you and what I'd lost.
Cheer up boyo. You look like a laxative commercial... before.
